prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Special Considerations with Regard to Injunctions

para.paratext: In some circumstances, the court has the ability to restrain the activity of third parties to whom information has been disclosed.[1] Where a third party is controlled or operated by the party who obtained information without authorization, the third party may be prevented from using the information.[2] Similarly, where an independent third party is “well aware that his co-defendants would bring to their new association information about the plaintiff's trade secret extracted from the plaintiff, intended to be used and actually used in the defendants' process”, an injunction will be granted.[3]

On the other hand, where the third party has no reason to believe that the confidential information was obtained or used without authorization, an injunction against the third party will not usually be granted.[4] Furthermore, if the information used forms only a small part of the third party's new product or idea, an injunction may be refused, although damages may be awarded.[5]
Haessler-DeWay Ltd. v. Color Tech Inc. (1985), 4 C.I.P.R. 77 at pp. 83–4, 49 C.P.C. 156 (Ont. Dist. Ct.).

Cradle Pictures (Canada) Ltd. v. Penner (1977), 34 C.P.R. (2d) 34 (Ont. H.C.J.), at p. 43; MacDonald v. Vapor Canada Ltd. (1972), 6 C.P.R. (2d) 204 (F.C.T.D.), vard 33 D.L.R. (3d) 434, [1972] F.C. 1156 (C.A.), revd on other grounds 66 D.L.R. (3d) 1, [1977] 2 S.C.R. 134.

International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar (1968), 67 D.L.R. (2d) 386 at pp. 391–2, [1968] 1 O.R. 669 (C.A.). See also Polyresins Ltd. v. Stein-Hall Ltd. (1971), 25 D.L.R. (3d) 152 at p. 159, [1972] 2 O.R. 188 (H.C.J.).
Krouse v. Chrysler Canada Ltd. (1971), 25 D.L.R. (3d) 49 at p. 57, [1972] 2 O.R. 133 (H.C.J.), revd on other grounds 40 D.L.R. (3d) 15, 1 O.R. (2d) 225 (C.A.).

Hubbard v. Vosper, [1972] 2 Q.B. 84 (C.A.), at p. 101. See also Expert Travel Financial Security (E.T.F.S.) Inc. v. BMS Harris & Dixon Insurance Brokers Ltd. (2005), 249 D.L.R. (4th) 367, 36 B.C.L.R. (4th) 254 (C.A.).
